citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The Program of Veterinary Care (PVC) states that the black bears and the ring tailed lemurs are to be vaccinated
annually for rabies. The bears were last vaccinated for rabies on 29 May 2019. The facility representative was not able to
provide vaccine records for the ring tailed lemurs and confirmed that they have not been vaccinated within the last year.
Failure to follow the directions for medical care in the PVC can lead to inadequate husbandry and preventive care. In this
case, these animals could be at risk for a preventable but fatal communicable disease. The facility must use appropriate
methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. This includes medical care directed by the
Program of Veterinary Care. To be corrected by 3 August 2023.

The facility's contingency plan has been in place and reviewed in a compliant time frame, however, a new employee
involved with the care of the animals started at the facility on 31 May 2023 and has not been trained on this contingency
plan. Failure to conduct training with employees involved with the operation of the facility and the care of the animals can
result in a less than optimal response in the event of an emergency. Exhibitors must provide training for their personnel
regarding their roles and responsibilities as outlined in the contingency plan. For employees hired more than 30 days after
the date the licensee or registrant puts its contingency plan in place, training must be conducted within 30 days of their
start date. Any substantive changes to the plan as a result of the annual review must be communicated to employees
through training which must be conducted within 30 days of making the changes. To be corrected by 3 August 2023.

One female Ring Tailed Lemur ("Louise") was found on 27 January 2023 with an injury to her left hand. The facility
reported it as one finger had been "degloved" and the end of the finger was missing with part of the bone visible. This
injury resulted in the amputation of this finger on the left hand. Housing facilities that do not protect animals from injury
can lead to pain, medical complications, and even death from injuries. The facility must ensure that housing facilities for
nonhuman primates be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of nonhuman
primates housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the
animals securely, and restrict other animals from entering. To be corrected by close of business on 29 July 2023.

The metal lining the egress door leading to the shelter structure in the serval enclosure is deteriorating, resulting in a
jagged edge. This metal is not sound and the jagged metal could result in injury to the animal. The facility must be
constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. The indoor and outdoor
housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and
to contain the animals. To be corrected by 27 August 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
